Posts.Content: Jun 8, 2011 12:12PM YoYo44 wrote: Hi Jaqueline, Thanks from me too. It's great seeing someone ahead breaking the trail.  Take care, Yo
Posts.Title: Need Help Please IllinoisNancy YoYo44

Posts.Content: Sep 4, 2009 12:26PM YoYo44 wrote: Hi, I asked my onc about this as I usually have a flu vaccine every year (my son has asthma).  I was more worried that I would not be able to get it because it would have a negative effect on me.  But he said he would not suggest it to me as my immune system is depressed and it would not mount an appropriate immune resonse to the vaccine to protect me.  Good point.  So I will not be geting it.  I am not sure what stage I will be in as I am supposed to finish my 12 weeks of Taxol week of Oct 11, then not sure if surgery or 4xAC first. Have a good weekend.  Yo

Posts.Content: Feb 24, 2010 08:16AM YoYo44 wrote: Hi Elizabeth, I just saw your name in passing and saw your latest news. I am sorry you are having to go through this.  I hope the visit with your Mom was OK-I know how hard that must have been. Sending you strong and positive thoughts, and any Monty Python thoughts I can think of too!  I agree with you, to quote readers digest,  "laughter is the best medicine" (although chemo is also pretty good...) Hugs,Yo.
Posts.Title: Really crappy news :-(((( konakat pee

Posts.Content: Jun 21, 2010 12:46PM - edited Jun 21, 2010 12:47PM by YoYo44 Congrats Jenn!!  I know you really had some tough times but you were truly indomitable and you made it through in high spirits.  You made treatment easier for me too. My 1 year will be July 3.  It was actually the biopsy date but the radiologist was so kind and she was honest.  When I asked her, what do you think, is it cancer, can it be anything else?  She said she was pretty certain it was cancer and the tests would confirm it.  And then she said, but you will be OK now, we will take care of you.  I know they don't usually tell you anything until the tests, but I was relieved to stop trying to think of what else it could be, as well as horrified that it was cancer of course. I am editing this to add that tomorrow is my last radiation treatment!  Yay!! Have a wonderful celebration Jenn!!! Yo
Posts.Title: ONE YEAR AGO TODAY...... jenn3 jenn3

Posts.Content: Oct 5, 2009 03:03PM YoYo44 wrote: Hi ladies, You know, it's really funny how different we all are and how dfferent our SE's are.  I am on neo-adjuvant Taxol (12x weekly) and 3 month Zoladex.  Minimal SE's.  At week 8 I got some neuropathy and my RBC's finally fell below normal but my WBC's are still normal.  I still have my hair although I am shedding a lot.  At some point it is going to start to look silly and I will shave it but for now it's OK.  Weird, huh?  I have a lot of fatigue but it is manageable and I am still working (I work from home and go to the office a few times a week).  But the Zoladex contributes a lot to the fatigue, etc.  I have not had any joint pain though, so that is great too. Hope that gives you some strength.  One foot in front of the other!!!!  Stay srtrong.  Have a great day!

Posts.Content: Oct 5, 2009 03:06PM YoYo44 wrote: Oops, forgot to say that last week was week 10.  This week at week 11 I will hear what the onc wants to do next-more chemo, surgery... Who knows. Have a good one!
Posts.Title: paclitaxel weekly gonnabstrong unklezwifeonty

Posts.Content: Sep 12, 2009 08:47AM YoYo44 wrote: Hi, I started with 12xTaxol, weekly.  I get 3 premeds (ranitidine, dexamethasone, and benadryl) which take about 30 mins.  Then the Taxol itself only takes 1 hour. I am very lucky.  I just had TX#7, still have my hair, although am losing a lot.  No neuropathy, anemia, joint pain or nausea.  Just having trouble sleeping and hot flashes.  But I am also on Zoladex, so who knows which is which for SE's. Good luck. Yo
Posts.Title: Taxol - How long does it take? Tabatha00 shadow38

Posts.Content: Jun 2, 2010 06:30AM YoYo44 wrote: Hi Ladies, Thanks for you comments.  I finished chemo March 18 and starting about a month afterwards I have been suffering the worst joint pain, especially knees and fingers (and elbows this week!!) that I have ever felt as well as numbness in both hands (not just the ALND side).  I have never had carpal tunnel but that is what I imagined it felt like.  Stairs have been brutal, even curbs have been daunting. Your comments give me hope, thanks!  My onc is sending me to a rhuematologist.  I guess we will see where that goes. All the best! Yo

I will share my strength and positive thinking with you and send it to help.  Stay strong. Hugs to you and your little brother and family. XOXOX Yo

Posts.Content: Feb 10, 2010 11:58AM YoYo44 wrote: Hi, I did 14 weeks from end of July to end of October.  It was OK but very tiring.  A real grind.  I just had 2/4 of FEC 100 now.  How are you doing? Yo
Posts.Title: Any Weekly Taxol takers? riverview817 AnacortesGirl

Posts.Content: Feb 20, 2010 02:55PM YoYo44 wrote: Hello Ladies, Hang in there Riverview.  I have heard of lots of ladies having a tough time with Taxol and many saying it is a breeze.  It is like everything, highly dependent on your body.  I found the Taxol manageable but the fatigue was tough.  Patty commented on early bedtime and I was agreeing with everything she said.  And the SE's are cummulative so cut yourself some slack as you go, you don't need to be superwoman, give yourself extra rest. Annacortes Girl, glad you are getting through as well.  I am on FEC100 x4 (3 week cycles) which is slightly milder than AC (mainly from the cardiotoxicity perspective-still has it but lower %).  Next Thursday will be 3/4, woohoo.  I am lucky, I am finding this a lot easier than the Taxol, no where near as fatigued.  Of course higher risk with WBC's too but they are hanging in OK so far.  Just heard about the radiation-will be 5 1/2 weeks, axilla and boob.  .  darn!!!!  Oh well, it is what it is.  This too shall pass... Be strong and have a great weekend ladies!
Posts.Title: Any Weekly Taxol takers? riverview817 AnacortesGirl

Posts.Content: Oct 23, 2009 09:46AM YoYo44 wrote: Hey Ang, Sorry to hear you will need chemo.  I know you are having a tough time already.  I cannot imagine how you are managing with your big family.  I have one 7 yr old son only and my husband pitches in a lot and it is still challenging with work and household. Try to be open about the chemo.  Remember it is a key weapon in your arsenal agains this evil BC and is there to make you better.  It is not forever. Not everyone has a bad time with it.  Probably a lot of women who do OK through it don't even come here or write so the info and comments you see is skewed.  Having said that everyone gets through it one way or the other and this site is great for support and true understanding.  (Not trying to preach or anything here, just trying to send you some ideas you can maybe latch onto to help you find a groove.) Comments from people like "stay positive" etc etc can start to grate.  Some days you just want to cry and pull the sheets over your head.  What I told my close friends about this was don't tell me to be positive but help me out with some humour because I don't want to cry any more than I need to 'cause it hurts my head!  Easier said than done!  I am blaming my tearfulness on my newly implemented menopause (I am only 44-funny, this is one of the few places I would be considered youngish anymore ) Someone in the August chemo group had a great line so I will use it here.  Get up and walk around your house and imagine you are walking over to Montreal so I can give you a big hug.  And put on your shawl so you will feel wrapped in love.  And perhaps a piece of chocolate taken here, medicinally of course, might help.    {{{Hugs}}} Yo
Posts.Title: Depressed Ang7 TXBadboob

Posts.Content: Apr 26, 2010 10:09AM YoYo44 wrote: Wow, some amazing comments.  I try to be understanding (works about 90% of the time...)as I think most people mean well and just don't know what to say.  But I have to say I am still a little at a loss for words when people look at me and say, wow, you look really good, I guess they caught it early.  But I also know that I didn't understood anything about bc before and what it means that a person is having chemo either.  Yet another learning opportunity!!!!  Have a good one! Yo
Posts.Title: OK another stupid comment comment DCMom ktn

Posts.Content: Jul 26, 2009 07:52PM YoYo44 wrote: What a horrible experience.  I am sorry to hear about your news.  One good thing I can say is that this is great forum with a lot of very informed people who are caring, compassionate and supportive. Definitely keep looking until you find a doctor that will answer your questions and make you feel confident and that you can trust.  I am pretty new to all this too and started off with a doctor at a clinic who was very abrupt, uncaring and impersonal.  But once I moved on with my diagnosis I have been very fortunate to have had very compassionate and caring medical people taking care of me.  As every one will say and I can recently atest to, you are in the worst, most scary time and a lot of it has to do with being out of control.  Hang in there, line up your questions and see another doctor.  It will get better and you will feel better.  Good luck.
Posts.Title: Feel like I am being jerked around... Ang7 SJW1
